title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 21 march [1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 21 March [1867]
text: â€”1867march 21 Dear walti got your letter yesterday with the money all safe i feel quite rich when i get it and dislike to change it but i have tooto for our georgy has been so hard for money lately that i dontdon't ask for it if i did and he had any i make no doubt but he would give it to me) Jeffy let him have 150 dolrdollars a few days ago O iveI've got a letter from han i have read it and will send it to you walt i was so glad to hear from her once more i thought when hattie brought it up it was from you i was a little frightened at first seeing your writing didentdidn't look at first at the burlington my not being in the habit of getting any only wensdaysWednesdays then i wachwatch for the messenger O dear walt aintain't we having it here in storms and gales of wind it is awful what times we have i have just got warm since morning i have put a blanket up to the window to keep the wind out when itsit's northeast itsit's almost impossible to keep warm i have had a pretty hard winter so far but am in hopes it will be over after a while it has been almost as much as your life was worth to get to the privy it is so decendingdescending and slippery i doodo hope i shant have to live here another winter i know i mighmight be much worse off but it is so bad for me to live up stairs such crooked ones as these they have company yet down stairs they go out almost every night last week i hardly went to bed till twelve or after they go to new york and come up in the last car last night they come about 12 jeff had a cup of tea here which made it almost 1 before i got to bed davis sDavis's cousin is here nearly half of his time Mr Rice and masons sister is here mat and she is going to philadelphe to morrow i hope when she comes back she will settle down and be a little like herself i hardly see her she sshe's so engaged in company and dress you know i wrote about sis swallowing the penypenny the next day morning matty and her friend went out so i kept sis and wachedwatched her and the penny passed through her when her mother came home she never asked any thing about it so i wouldentwouldn't tell her i told jeff he was very much worried but but she sshe's all well she says she calafornia when uncle comes home well walt i cantcan't write much more my arm gets so weak and lame it is quite troublsometroublesome i am in hopes when the weather becomes warmer it will get better George has just been up and tells me they have sold one of the houses to the captain he was captain of the contest taken by the alabamans in the war times) this peicepiece was cut out of the williamsburg timesWilliamsburgh Times good bie walter dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 21 March [1867]
